com.ibm.streamsx.topology

Interface TStream<T>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - Tuple type, any instance of T at runtime must be serializable.
    All Superinterfaces:
    TopologyElement
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    SPLStream

    public interface TStream<T>
extends TopologyElement
    A TStream is a declaration of a continuous sequence of tuples. A connected topology of streams and functional transformations is built using Topology.
    Generic methods on this interface provide the ability to filter, transform or sink this declared stream using a function.
    Utility methods in the com.ibm.streams.topology.streams package provide specific source streams, or transformations on streams with specific types.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Interface and Description
      static class  TStream.Routing
      Enumeration for routing tuples to parallel channels.

    • Method Detail

      • filter

        TStream<T> filter(Predicate<T> filter)
        Declare a new stream that filters tuples from this stream. Each tuple t on this stream will appear in the returned stream if filter.test(t) returns true. If filter.test(t) returns false then then t will not appear in the returned stream.

        Example of filtering out all empty strings from stream s of type String 

         
 Stream<String> s = ...
 Stream<String> filtered = s.filter(new Predicate<String>() {
             @Override
             public boolean test(String t) {
                 return !t.isEmpty();
             }} );

        Parameters:
        filter - Filtering logic to be executed against each tuple.
        Returns:
        Filtered stream

      • transform

        <U> TStream<U> transform(Function<T,U> transformer,
                       java.lang.Class<U> tupleTypeClass)
        Declare a new stream that transforms each tuple from this stream into one (or zero) tuple of a different type U. For each tuple t on this stream, the returned stream will contain a tuple that is the result of transformer.call(t) when the return is not null .

        Example of transforming a stream containing numeric values as Strings into a stream of Double values. 

         
 Stream<String> strings = ...
 Stream<Double> doubles = strings.transform(new Function() {
             @Override
             public Double call(String v) {
                 return Double.valueOf(v);
             }}, Double.class );

        Parameters:
        transformer - Transformation logic to be executed against each tuple.
        tupleTypeClass - Type U of the returned stream.
        Returns:
        Stream contained tuples of type U transformed from this stream's tuples.

      • modify

        TStream<T> modify(UnaryOperator<T> modifier)

      • multiTransform

        <U> TStream<U> multiTransform(Function<T,java.lang.Iterable<U>> transformer,
                            java.lang.Class<U> tupleTypeClass)
        Declare a new stream that transforms tuples from this stream into one or more (or zero) tuples of a different type U. For each tuple t on this stream, the returned stream will contain all tuples in the Iterator<U> that is the result of transformer.call(t) . Tuples will be added to the returned stream in the order the iterator returns them.
        If the return is null or an empty iterator then no tuples are added to the return stream for input tuple t. when the return is not null.

        Example of transforming a stream containing lines of text into a stream of words split out from each line. The order of the words in the stream will match the order of the words in the lines. 

         
 Stream<String> lines = ...
 Stream<String> words = lines.multiTransform(new Function>() {
             @Override
             public Iterable call(String t) {
                 return Arrays.asList(t.split(" "));
             }}, String.class);

        Parameters:
        transformer - Transformation logic to be executed against each tuple.
        tupleTypeClass - Type U of the returned stream.
        Returns:
        Stream contained tuples of type U transformed from this stream's tuples.

      • sink

        void sink(Consumer<T> sinker)
        Sink (terminate) this stream. For each tuple t on this stream sinker.accept(t) will be called. This is typically used to send information to external systems, such as databases or dashboards.

        Example of terminating a stream of String tuples by printing them to System.out. 

         
 Stream<String> values = ...
 values.sink(new FunctionV() {
             
             @Override
             public void accept(String v) {
                 System.out.println(v);
                 
             }
         });

        Parameters:
        sinker - Logic to be executed against each tuple on this stream.

      • union

        TStream<T> union(TStream<T> other)
        Create a stream that is a union of this stream and other stream of the same type T. Any tuple on this stream or other will appear on the returned stream.
        No ordering of tuples across this stream and other is defined, thus the return stream is unordered.
        Parameters:
        other - Stream to union with this stream.
        Returns:
        Stream that will contain tuples from this stream and other.

      • union

        TStream<T> union(java.util.Set<TStream<T>> others)
        Create a stream that is a union of this stream and others streams of the same type T. Any tuple on this stream or any of others will appear on the returned stream.
        No ordering of tuples across this stream and others is defined, thus the return stream is unordered.
        If others does not contain any streams then this is returned.
        Parameters:
        others - Streams to union with this stream.
        Returns:
        Stream containing tuples from this stream and others.

      • print

        void print()
        Print each tuple on System.out. For each tuple t on this stream System.out.println(t.toString()) will be called.

      • getTupleClass

        java.lang.Class<T> getTupleClass()

      • join

        <J,U> TStream<J> join(TWindow<U> window,
                    BiFunction<T,java.lang.Iterable<U>,J> joiner,
                    java.lang.Class<J> tupleClass)
        Join this stream with window of type U. For each tuple on this stream, it is joined with the contents of other. Each tuple is passed into joiner and the return value is submitted to the returned stream. If call returns null then no tuple is submitted.
        Parameters:
        joiner -
        Returns:
        A stream that is the results of joining this stream with window.

      • last

        TWindow<T> last(long time,
              java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit unit)
        Declare a TWindow that represents the last time seconds of tuples (in the given time unit) on this stream.
        When T implements Keyable then the window is partitioned using the value of Keyable.getKey(). In this case that means each partition independently maintains the last time seconds of tuples for that key.

      • last

        TWindow<T> last(int count)
        Declare a TWindow that represents the last count tuples on this stream.
        When T implements Keyable then the window is partitioned using the value of Keyable.getKey(). In this case that means each partition independently maintains the last count tuples for that key.

      • last

        TWindow<T> last()
        Declare a TWindow that represents the last tuple on this stream.
        When T implements Keyable then the window is partitioned using the value of Keyable.getKey(). In this case that means each partition independently maintains the last tuple for that key.

      • window

        TWindow<T> window(TWindow<?> configWindow)
        Declare a TWindow on this stream that has the same configuration as another window.. When T implements Keyable then the window is partitioned using the value of Keyable.getKey(). In this case that means each partition independently maintains the list of tuples for that key.
        Parameters:
        configWindow - Window to copy the configuration from.

      • publish

        void publish(java.lang.String topic)
        Publish tuples from this stream to allow other applications to consume them using:
        • Topology.subscribe(String, Class) for Java Streams applications.
        • com.ibm.streamsx.topology.topic::Subscribe operator for SPL Streams applications.

        A subscriber matches to a publisher if:
        • The topic is an exact match.
        • For Java streams (Stream&lt;T>), the declared Java type (T ) of the stream is an exact match.
        • For SPL streams, the SPL scehma is an exact match.

      • parallel

        TStream<T> parallel(int width)
        Parallelizes the stream into width parallel channels. If the tuple implements Keyable, the parallel channels are partitioned. Otherwise, the parallel channels are not partitioned, and tuples are routed in a round-robin fashion.

        See the documentation for parallel(int, Routing) for more information.
        Parameters:
        width - The degree of parallelism in the parallel region.
        Returns:
        A reference to a stream for which subsequent operations will be part of the parallel region.

      • parallel

        TStream<T> parallel(int width,
                  TStream.Routing routing)
        Parallelizes the stream into width parallel channels. Tuples are routed to the parallel channels based on the TStream.Routing parameter. If ROUND_ROBIN is specified, the tuples are routed to parallel channels such that an even distribution is maintained. If PARTITIONED is specified and the tuple implements the Keyable interface, then the tuple is routed to a parallel channel according to the hashCode() of the object returned by getKey(). If PARTITIONED is specified and the tuple does not implement the Keyable interface, then the hashCode() of the tuple is used to route the tuple to a corresponding channel.

        Given the following code: 
         
 TStream<String> myStream = ...;
 TStream<String> parallel_start = myStream.parallel(3, TStream.Routing.ROUND_ROBIN);
 TStream<String> in_parallel = parallel_start.filter(...).transform(...);
 TStream<String> joined_parallel_streams = in_parallel.unparallel();
        a visual representation a visual representation for parallel() would be as follows: 
         
                  |----filter----transform----|
                  |                           |
 ---myStream------|----filter----transform----|--joined_parallel_streams
                  |                           |
                  |----filter----transform----|
        Each parallel channel can be thought of as being assigned its own thread. As such, each parallelized stream function (filter and transform, in this case) operate independently from one another.

        parallel() will only parallelize the stream operations performed after the call to parallel() and before the call to unparallel(). In the above example, the parallel() was invoked on myStream, so its subsequent functions, filter() and transform(), were parallelized.

        Parallel regions aren't required to have an output stream, and thus may be used as sinks. The following would be an example of a parallel sink: 
         
 TStream<String> myStream = ...;
 TStream<String> myParallelStream = myStream.parallel(6);
 myParallelStream.print();
        myParallelStream will be printed to output in parallel. In other words, a parallel sink is created by calling parallel(int) and creating a sink operation (such as sink(Consumer)). It is not necessary to invoke unparallel() on parallel sinks.

        Limitations of parallel() are as follows:
        Nested parallelism is not currently supported. A call to parallel() should never be made immediately after another call to parallel() without having an unparallel() in between.

        Parallel() should not be invoked immediately after another call to parallel(). The following is invalid: 
         
 myStream.parallel(2).parallel(2);
        There must be at least one stream function between a parallel() and unparallel() invocation. The following is invalid: 
         
 myStream.parallel(2).unparallel();
        Every call to unparallel() must have a call to parallel preceding it. The following is invalid: 
         
 Stream myStream = topology.strings("a","b","c");
 myStream.unparallel();
        A parallelized Stream cannot be joined with another window, and a parallelized Window cannot be joined with a Stream. The following is invalid: 
         
 Window numWindow = topology.strings("1","2","3").last(3);
 Stream stringStream = topology.strings("a","b","c");
 Stream paraStringStream = myStream.parallel(5);
 Stream filtered = myStream.filter(...);
 filtered.join(numWindow, ...);
        Parameters:
        width - The degree of parallelism. see parallel(int width) for more details.
        routing - A TStream enum: ROUND_ROBIN or PARTITIONED. If PARTITIONED is specified, and the tuple doesn't implement Keyable, it will partition based on the tuple's Object hashCode().
        Returns:
        A reference to a TStream<> at the beginning of the parallel region.

      • unparallel

        TStream<T> unparallel()
        unparallel() merges the parallel channels of a parallelized stream. returns a Stream<T> for which subsequent operations will not be performed in parallel. Additionally, it merges any partitions which may have been present in the parallel channels.

        For additional documentation, see parallel(int)
        Returns:
        A Stream<T> for which subsequent operations are no longer parallelized.

      • sample

        TStream<T> sample(double fraction)
        Return a stream that is a random sample of this stream.
        Parameters:
        fraction - Fraction of the data to return.
        Returns:
        Stream containing a random sample of this stream.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - fraction is less that or equal to zero or greater than 1.0.

      • throttle

        TStream<T> throttle(long delay,
                  java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit unit)
        Throttle a stream by ensuring any tuple is submitted with least delay from the previous tuple.
        Parameters:
        delay - Maximum amount to delay a tuple.
        unit - Unit of delay.
        Returns:
        Stream containing all tuples on this stream. but throttled.

      • output

        BOutput output()

      • connectTo

        BInputPort connectTo(BOperatorInvocation receivingBop,
                   boolean functional,
                   BInputPort input)
        Connect this stream to a downstream operator. If input is null then a new input port will be created, otherwise it will be used to connect to this stream. Returns input or the new port if input was null.
